title: How to Make Ice Cream Without a Machine

steps.headline: Place a 13 by 9 inch (about 33 by 23 cm) pan in the freezer.
steps.description: Leave your pan in the freezer so it gets cool to the touch. While your pan freezes, work on mixing your other ingredients. By the time you're done with other ingredients, your pan should be cold enough to use.

steps.headline: Stir your ingredients together.
steps.description: Place all your ingredients in a large mixing bowl. Use a spoon to mix the ingredients together or use your hand mixer. Mix the ingredients together until the sugar dissolves.

steps.headline: Freeze your mixture for 20 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Remove your pan from the freezer. Transfer the ingredients to the pan and place it back in the freezer. Freeze the ingredients for about 20 to 30 minutes. The mixture should be kept in the freezer until the edges just start to freeze.

steps.headline: Use the hand mixer to mix your ice cream.
steps.description: Beat the mixture with the hand mixer until it develops a smooth, creamy texture. Times will vary depending on how cold your mixture got. When you're done, the mixture should have a smooth and creamy texture. At this point, it should have a consistency very similar to ice cream.

steps.headline: Repeat this pattern until the ice cream is firm.
steps.description: Place the mixture back in the freezer and freeze it for an additional 20 to 30 minutes. Then, use the hand mixer to beat your mixture until it's smooth. Repeat this process until your ice cream is frozen throughout. It is now ready to eat. The number of repetitions needed depends on the temperature of your freezer. Warmer freezers will take longer to freeze your ice cream.

steps.headline: Whisk together your egg yolk and half the sugar.
steps.description: Place your egg yolk and half the sugar in a mixing bowl. Use a wire whisk to beat the egg yolk and sugar together. Keep beating until everything is mixed evenly. Then, set this mixture aside for now.

steps.headline: Heat the cream, half-and-half, remaining sugar, and salt.
steps.description: In a pot, mix your cream, half-and-half, remaining sugar, and salt. Place the pot over medium-high heat. Stir the mixture often. Bring the mixture to a simmer and then reduce the heat to medium.

steps.headline: Add half a cup of the egg yolk mixture.
steps.description: Pour half a cup of your egg yolk mixture into the cream, half-and-half, and salt mixture. Add the egg yolk mixture gradually while whisking the half-and-half mixture constantly. Keep pouring and whisking until all the ingredients are evenly combined.

steps.headline: Repeat the process with another half cup.
steps.description: Add another half a cup of the egg yolk mixture to the pot. Repeat the exact same process. Pour the mixture in gradually while whisking constantly to mix everything together.

steps.headline: Stir the mixture with a spatula over heat.
steps.description: Use a heat proof spatula. Keeping the pot over medium heat, stir the mixture constantly. Cook the mixture until it begins to thicken. Times will vary depending on the precise heat of your stove. Once the mixture begins to coat the spatula, cook it for an additional one to two minutes before removing it from the heat.

steps.headline: Strain the mixture.
steps.description: Get a clean bowl and a fine mesh sieve. Strain the mixture into the clean bowl through the sieve.

steps.headline: Add the vanilla.
steps.description: Use a wire whisk and vigorously beat the ingredients together. Keep whisking everything together until it's mixed evenly.

steps.headline: Place the mixture in an ice bath and stir.
steps.description: Fill a larger bowl with ice. Place the bowl with your ingredients into the ice bath. Use a wire whisk to stir the mixture occasionally. Keep the bowl in the ice bath until the mixture cools to room temperature.

steps.headline: Freeze the mixture.
steps.description: Take the bowl out of the ice bath. Cover it completely with plastic wrap. Freeze the bowl for at least two hours. However, it's best to freeze the bowl overnight. Make sure the bowl you're using is freezer safe. If it's not, transfer the mixture to a freezer safe bowl.

steps.headline: Whisk the mixture into the right consistency.
steps.description: When you're ready to serve the ice cream, use a spatula or wire whisk to vigorously churn the mixture. This will remove any ice chunks and get it to a creamy texture. Then, place it back in the freezer for 30 minutes and stir it again. Repeat this process until you have a light, fluffy texture.

steps.headline: Whisk the egg yolks, sugar, vanilla, and salt.
steps.description: Use a wire whisk to beat the egg yolks, vanilla, and sugar together in a mixing bowl. Beat everything together until the ingredients are evenly combined. When done, the mixture will have a pale yellow color. This generally takes around five minutes.

steps.headline: Heat your evaporated milk.
steps.description: Place your evaporated milk in a medium sauce pan. Heat it over the stovetop until it comes to a simmer. Stir the evaporated milk constantly as it heats.

steps.headline: Add the milk to your egg mixture.
steps.description: Add the milk to your egg mixture gradually. Pour in small amounts at a time while whisking the batter constantly. Make sure all the ingredients are evenly mixed before proceeding.

steps.headline: Heat your mixture.
steps.description: Transfer the milk and egg mixture back to the sauce pan. Heat the mixture until it forms a thick, custardy texture. It will be about 180 degrees Fahrenheit (about 82 degrees Celsius) when done. Make sure not to overheat the mixture, as this will cause the eggs to scramble.

steps.headline: Chill the mixture.
steps.description: Place the mixture in a freezer-safe bowl. Place it in the freezer or fridge until it's cool throughout. Times vary depending on the precise temperature of your fridge or freezer.

steps.headline: Whip your cream.
steps.description: Place one cup (240 mL) of your heavy cream in a mixing bowl. Whisk it together vigorously using a wire whisk until it forms whipped cream. The amount of time varies depending on how fast you're able to whip the cream.

steps.headline: Add your whipped cream to your ice cream mixture.
steps.description: Pour the whipped cream into your chilled ice cream mixture. Use a spoon to gently fold the ingredients together. Everything should be completely incorporated when you're done. You should be left with a smooth batter without any visible lumps.

steps.headline: Place your mixture in ice cube trays.
steps.description: Take an ice cube tray. Use a spoon to fill each component with your batter. If necessary, use more than one tray. The amount of trays needed depend on the size trays you're using.

steps.headline: Freeze your batter for four hours.
steps.description: Place your ice cube trays filled with batter in the freezer. Freeze them for about four hours. Most freezers should freeze the batter in this time frame. However, do not remove the batter until it's solid. Warmer freezers may require more time.

steps.headline: Combine the frozen cubes and remaining cream in a food processor.
steps.description: Add your ice cream cubes to the food processor. Pour in the remaining cream. Turn on the food processor and allow the ingredients to mix together until everything is smooth. This usually takes about 30 seconds.

steps.headline: Freeze your mixture four more hours before serving.
steps.description: Place the mixture in a sealable freezer-safe container. Freeze your batter for about four hours before serving.

steps.headline: Finished.
